references.title: On the Impact Origin of Phobos and Deimos. IV. Volatile Depletion
references.adopted_scope: Post-impact radiative cooling and volatile loss for gas-poor Martian debris disks.
claims: Equations (2)–(4) provide the radiative-slab cooling law used for Mars surface temperatures (E.042).
Equations (5)–(6) relate particle temperature, ⟨Q_abs⟩, and the dilution factor √(R_p/2r) (E.043).
Discusses the few-orbit volatile escape and β-threshold regimes adopted by the simulation.
Serves as the primary citation for siO2_disk_cooling.tmars/tp_of_rt and radiation.grain_temperature_graybody.

references.title: On the Impact Origin of Phobos and Deimos I: Thermodynamic and Physical Aspects
references.adopted_scope: Initial conditions of Martian debris disks immediately after the giant impact (molten-rich).
claims: Shows the disk consists of >95 wt% melt and <5 wt% vapor at ~2000 K right after impact.
Links eccentric orbits and particle-size cascades from meter-scale fragments down to 100 µm–0.1 µm grains.

references.title: On the Impact Origin of Phobos and Deimos II: True Polar Wander and Disk Evolution
references.adopted_scope: Dynamical relaxation of the post-impact disk, including J2-driven precession and inelastic damping.
claims: Shows how J2 precession coupled with inelastic collisions circularises the disk inside the Roche limit.
Demonstrates the resulting radial density contrast (dense inner disk, dilute outer disk).

references.title: On the Impact Origin of Phobos and Deimos III: Resulting Composition from Different Impactors
references.adopted_scope: Chemical contrasts between gas-phase condensates and quenched melts in Martian impact disks.
claims: Explores how vapor condensates and molten-solidified grains diverge compositionally depending on the impactor.
Supplies the thermochemical motivation for sublimation parameters and SiO-rich sinks.

references.title: Reconciling the orbital and physical properties of the Martian moons with a giant impact origin
references.adopted_scope: Condensation and spectral signatures of dust condensing in the outer gas envelope of a Martian impact disk.
claims: Argues that condensation in the outer tenuous gas envelope best matches the observed spectra of Phobos/Deimos.
Shows magma-ocean sourced material alone cannot reproduce the remote-sensing constraints.

references.title: Formation of Regular Satellites from Ancient Massive Rings
references.adopted_scope: Viscous spreading regimes of dense rings near the Roche limit and their satellite-feeding outcomes.
claims: Slow diffusion leads to trains of growing satellites with mass increasing with orbital distance.
Rapid diffusion yields a single dominant moon accreting most of the ring material.

references.title: Origin of Phobos and Deimos by the impact of a Vesta-to-Ceres-sized body with Mars
references.adopted_scope: Constraints on disk mass and planetary tidal parameters required for Phobos/Deimos survival.
claims: Small moons survive only when M_disk ≤ 3×10⁻⁵ M_Mars and the tidal parameter (Q/k₂) < 80 (Fig. 2).
Establishes the low-mass, low-gas default assumed in configs and analysis recipes.

references.title: Dust Dynamics, Surface Brightness Profiles, and Thermal Spectra of Debris Disks: The Case of AU Mic
references.adopted_scope: Optically thin, gas-poor debris disks where radiation pressure and CPR drag set the small-grain budget.
claims: Equation (1) gives the collisional time-scale t_c = 1/(Ω τ_⊥) adopted in S1 surface updates and (E.006).
Defines β(s), the β = 0.5 blow-out limit, and the type A/B regimes with τ(r) ∝ r^{-5/2} or r^{-3/2}.
Provides the gas-poor baseline for radiation.beta, blowout_radius, and related diagnostics; Wyatt (2008) is retained as a review-only cross-check.

references.title: Dust Outflows in Optically Thick Gas Disks
references.adopted_scope: Optically thick, gas-rich disk surfaces where stellar radiation pressure couples with gas drag to drive flows.
claims: Derives the TL2003 surface-layer ODE referenced only when ALLOW_TL2003=true.
Notes that net flow is inward under standard parameters; outward flow requires gas-rich, illuminated skins.

references.title: MMX-era review of Martian satellite origin scenarios
references.adopted_scope: Mission context for MMX and the comparative analysis of capture vs impact hypotheses.
claims: Summarises observational requirements feeding β/mass-loss scans.
Sets expectations for gas-poor vs capture interpretations.

references.title: Evolution of Debris Disks
references.adopted_scope: Collisional cascades in optically thin debris disks.
claims: Provides historical context for t_coll ≈ T_orb/(4π τ) scaling used before adopting Strubbe & Chiang.
Governs qualitative stability tests in surface-layer IMEX steps.

references.title: Radiation forces on small particles in the solar system
references.adopted_scope: Classical treatment of Q_pr, beta, and blow-out sizes for small particles under solar-system radiation forces.
claims: Defines the radiation-to-gravity ratio beta and connects it to blow-out limits and the Planck-mean efficiency Q_pr.
Provides the baseline beta(s) expression reused for the gas-poor, optically thin limit.

references.title: Solar System Dynamics
references.bibtex: @book{MurrayDermott1999_SSD, title = {Solar System Dynamics}, publisher = {Cambridge University Press}, year = {1999}, author = {Murray, C. D. and Dermott, S. F.}}
references.adopted_scope: Keplerian orbital relations and circular-orbit kinematics for planetary systems.
claims: Derives v_K = sqrt(GM/r) and Omega = sqrt(GM/r^3) for circular orbits from Newtonian gravity.
Provides canonical notation for v_K and Omega used throughout the repository.

references.title: Growth of Planets from Planetesimals
references.bibtex: @incollection{LissauerStewart1993_PP3, booktitle = {Protostars and Planets III}, year = {1993}, author = {Lissauer, J. J. and Stewart, G. R.}}
references.adopted_scope: Review of planetesimal dynamics and relative velocities under Rayleigh-distributed eccentricities and inclinations.
claims: Presents the low-e, low-i relative velocity scaling v_rel = v_K sqrt(1.25 e^2 + i^2) used for debris disks and rings.

references.title: Formation of planetary embryos: efficiencies of accretion and fragmentation
references.adopted_scope: Planetesimal collision rates and relative velocities in the low-e, low-i regime.
claims: Uses the v_rel ≈ v_K sqrt(1.25 e^2 + i^2) scaling for Rayleigh-distributed eccentricities and inclinations.

references.title: Dust distributions in debris disks: effects of gravity, radiation pressure and collisions
references.adopted_scope: nσv-style collisional cascades with Gaussian vertical structure and adaptive time stepping.
claims: Derives collision kernels proportional to cross section times relative speed divided by the combined scale height.
Uses adaptive time stepping and mass conservation checks for Smoluchowski solvers in debris-disk contexts.

references.title: Catastrophic Disruptions Revisited
references.adopted_scope: Material-dependent catastrophic disruption thresholds for rocky bodies at km/s impact speeds.
claims: Provides the basalt Q*_D coefficients used in Leinhardt & Stewart style interpolations at 3 and 5 km/s.

references.title: Collisions between gravity-dominated bodies. I. Outcome regimes and scaling laws
references.adopted_scope: Scaling laws and regime maps for catastrophic disruption across gravity- and strength-dominated impacts.
claims: Defines the velocity-dependent interpolation between strength and gravity regimes that underpins Q*_D(s, rho, v).

references.title: Velocity-dependent catastrophic disruption criteria for planetesimals
references.adopted_scope: Universal largest-remnant scaling and the reduced specific impact energy Q_R formalism.
claims: Introduces Q_R = 0.5 μ v^2 / M_tot and the piecewise largest-remnant fraction used for disruptive impacts.
Calibrates the φ<1 linear branch and φ≥1 power-law branch adopted in our F2 fragment model.

references.title: Evolution of planetesimal velocities based on analytic solution of the Boltzmann equation
references.adopted_scope: Analytic expressions for relative velocities and velocity dispersion in low-e, low-i planetesimal disks.
claims: Provides the v_rel ≈ v_K sqrt(1.25 e^2 + i^2) scaling used for mutual velocities.
Describes collisional cooling vs. shear heating balance that motivates the fixed-point iteration for c_eq.
